choices.text: Only i, ii and iii are correct
Only i and iii are correct
Only ii and iv are correct

questions.text:
Transitional cell carcinomas can be caused by which of the following etiological factor(s)?
i.Naphthylamine
ii.Cigarette smoking
iii.Schistosomiasis
iv.Long term use of antibiotics
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Risk factors for transitional cell cancer among the given options include naphthylamine, cigarette smoking, and schistosomiasis.

  • Transitional cell carcinoma, also known as urothelial carcinoma, is the most prevalent type of bladder cancer, making up about 90% of cases.
  • It originates from the urothelium and may present as multifocal tumors anywhere along the urinary tract, from the renal pelvis to the urethra.
  • The two main precursor lesions are noninvasive papillary tumors and flat carcinoma in situ (CIS), with the latter being high-grade and often progressing to invasive disease.
  • Once the muscularis propria is invaded, the prognosis worsens significantly.
  • Cigarette smoking is the most prominent risk factor and occupational exposure to aryl amines like 2-naphthylamine also plays a significant role, especially in industrial settings, with latency periods of 15 to 40 years.
  • Infections with Schistosoma haematobium (notably in Egypt and Sudan) can also cause transitional cell carcinoma though it is more commonly associated with squamous cell carcinoma.
  • Chronic use of analgesics, long-term cyclophosphamide therapy, and pelvic irradiation are other risk factors.
  • Age (50-80 years), male gender (3:1 ratio), urban living, and high-income status are epidemiological associations, though familial inheritance is rare.

choices.text: Transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder
Schistosoma haematobium infection of the bladder

questions.text: A 37-year-old male presents to his family physician with complaints of blood in his urine. A urine analysis reveals 4+ blood, with microscopic clots identified. The patient returned home 2 months ago after a missionary trip to Africa. He does not smoke nor drink alcohol. He has no family history of hereditary disorders. Of the following, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario of microscopic clots in blood after a trip to Africa suggests a diagnosis of Schistosoma haematobium infection of the bladder.

  • Schistosoma haematobium, found in Africa, targets the bladder, causing chronic granulomatous inflammation that can result in hematuria, obstruction, and even bladder cancer, mainly squamous cell cancer.
  • Transmission requires freshwater snails as intermediate hosts, and acute illness typically appears about two months after infection.
  • The pathology stems from host immune responses to different stages of the parasite's lifecycle.
  • After penetrating the skin, larvae migrate via blood and lymphatics to the bladder.
  • Infections with Schistosoma haematobium initially cause inflammatory cystitis due to heavy deposition of eggs and granuloma formation, resulting in mucosal ulceration and blood in the urine.
  • Over time, these granulomas can become calcified, forming a gritty texture that may extensively coat the bladder wall, producing a radiologically visible dense ring known as a "calcified bladder."
  • The most common outcome of this infection is chronic inflammation and scarring of the ureters, which can cause urinary blockage, swelling of the kidneys (hydronephrosis), and persistent kidney infection (chronic pyelonephritis).

Explanation of other options:

Transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder (Option A): Transitional cell carcinoma commonly presents with painless hematuria, along with urinary symptoms such as urgency and dysuria. Key risk factors include cigarette smoking,industrial exposure to aryl amines (like 2-naphthylamine), Schistosoma haematobium infection (especially in endemic areas), prolonged use of analgesics, chronic cyclophosphamide therapy, and prior pelvic irradiation.

Renal cell carcinoma (Option B): The most common adult kidney cancer, typically affects older adults, with a strong male predominance and peak incidence in the sixth and seventh decades. The most important risk factor is cigarette smoking, hypertension, estrogen exposure, heavy metals, and genetic syndromes like Von Hippel-Lindau. Clinically, patients may present with the classic triad of hematuria, flank pain, and a palpable mass, but it is uncommon to present with all three.

Membranous nephropathy (Option D): Membranous nephropathy is defined by a diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall due to immune complex deposition containing immunoglobulins along the subepithelial side of the basement membrane. About 75% of cases are primary and idiopathic, while the rest are secondary to identifiable causes like drugs (e.g., NSAIDs, penicillamine, captopril, gold) or systemic diseases.

questions.text: Which ONE of the following is the commonest type of bladder tumour?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Two distinct precursor lesions of invasive urothelial carcinoma are recognized. The most common is a non invasive papillary tumour.
The other precursor is carcinoma in situ (CIS), which is discussed later. In about one-half of patients with invasive bladder cancer, no precursor lesion is found; in such cases, it is presumed that the precursor lesion was overgrown by the high-grade invasive component.
Adenocarcinomas of the bladder are rare. Carcinoma of the bladder is more common in men than in women, in industrialized than in developing nations, in urban than in rural dwellers.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man has complained of pain during urination for the past week. He is afebrile and on cystoscopy, a slightly erythematous 1 cm diameter area is seen on the bladder mucosa. This area is biopsied and on microscopic examination shows cells with marked hyperchromatism and increased nuclear/cytoplasmic ratio involving the full thickness of the epithelium. However, these changes are confined to the epithelium above the basement membrane. Which of the following terms is used to best describe these biopsy findings?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The described lesion of dysplastic cells traversing the entire epithelium but remaining above the basement membrane is described by the term carcinoma in situ.

  • Carcinoma in situ refers to a condition where dysplasia affects the entire thickness of the epithelium without breaching the basement membrane.
  • This form of carcinoma is commonly found in areas such as the skin, breast, bladder, and cervix.
  • Although these lesions show all the cellular characteristics of cancer, they remain non-invasive unless untreated, at which point they carry a high risk of progressing to invasive malignancies.
  • Urothelial neoplasms constitute nearly 90% of all bladder tumors and encompass a spectrum from benign growths to aggressive, often fatal malignancies. Two main precursor lesions that lead to invasive urothelial carcinoma are noninvasive papillary tumors and flat noninvasive carcinoma in situ (CIS).
  • Noninvasive papillary tumors stem from urothelial hyperplasia and show a range of atypia, classified by their biological behavior. In contrast, CIS refers to flat urothelial lesions displaying malignant cytological features yet confined to the epithelium without breaching the basement membrane.
  • CIS is considered high-grade and commonly multifocal. On cystoscopy, CIS often presents as mucosal reddening or thickening without an obvious mass.
  • A key feature of CIS is pagetoid spread, where malignant cells are scattered within normal epithelium. The lack of cell cohesion in CIS allows malignant cells to shed into urine, sometimes leaving only a few clinging to a denuded basement membrane.
  • If left untreated, 50% to 75% of CIS cases evolve into invasive cancer.

Following are the morphological patterns of urothelial neoplasms.

Explanations of other options:

Metaplasia (Option A): Refers to the substitution of one mature cell type by another, typically in response to chronic irritation or tissue damage. This adaptive mechanism allows the new cell type to better tolerate the altered environment. A classical example is found in Barrett esophagus, where chronic acid reflux damages the native squamous lining, which is then replaced by glandular epithelium (either gastric or intestinal type) that is more suited to withstand the acidic surroundings. Though this replacement may be initially protective, metaplastic cells carry a risk of undergoing malignant transformation.

Dysplasia (Option B): Dysplasia is a precancerous condition typically seen in epithelial tissues. It is characterized by cellular atypia, including pleomorphism (variation in cell shape and size), prominent hyperchromatic nuclei with an increased nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio, and architectural disarray of the epithelial layer. In dysplastic epithelium, there is often a failure of orderly cell maturation, as seen in squamous epithelium where the normal progression of cells from the basal layer to the surface is disrupted.

Hyperplasia (Option D): Hyperplasia refers to an increase in the number of cells within a tissue or organ, occurring in response to a specific stimulus. This process is distinct from hypertrophy, which involves cell enlargement, although both may happen simultaneously and often share common triggers.

questions.text: The morphological finding of the kidney shown in the figure is associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given kidney specimen reveals small, pinpoint petechial hemorrhages on the cortical surface responsible for the characteristic "flea-bitten" appearance which is seen in malignant hypertension.

  • Malignant hypertension leads to a variety of vascular changes in the kidney depending on the severity and duration of the disease. The kidneys may be of normal size or appear shrunken.
  • A key gross feature is the presence of pinpoint petechial hemorrhages on the cortical surface due to rupture of glomerular capillaries or arterioles, imparting a characteristic "flea-bitten" appearance.
  • Microscopically, arteriolar damage manifests as fibrinoid necrosis, where the walls show intense eosinophilic granular appearance from necrotic debris and plasma protein leakage.
  • In the larger arterioles and interlobular arteries, intimal smooth muscle cell proliferation leads to hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis giving rise to an onion skin appearance.
  • This results in luminal narrowing or even obliteration of affected vessels, compromising perfusion.
  • Necrosis can also involve glomeruli, sometimes with microthrombi seen in glomerular capillaries.

Explanation of other options:

Chronic pyelonephritis (Option A): In chronic pyelonephritis, the defining feature is the presence of uneven, coarse scars at the junction of the cortex and medulla. There is associated blunting of calyces and loss of papillary architecture. This damage may be found in one or both kidneys. However, when both kidneys are affected, the pattern of scarring is irregular and non-uniform, in contrast to chronic glomerulonephritis, where the damage tends to be symmetrically distributed across the renal surface.

Renal amyloidosis (Option B): Amyloidosis of the kidney often affects the glomeruli first. Grossly, kidneys can be normal in appearance or appear shrunken in advanced stages due to ischemic injury from amyloid-induced vascular narrowing. Histologically, amyloid deposits accumulate in the glomerular mesangium and along basement membranes, causing narrowing of capillary lumens and distortion of the glomerular tuft. As the disease advances, the capillary lumens are progressively obliterated, and the glomerular architecture is replaced by dense, confluent amyloid material that may appear as interlacing broad ribbons. The interstitial areas, arteries, and arterioles are also secondarily affected by the amyloid infiltration.

Acute pyelonephritis (Option D): In acute pyelonephritis, one or both kidneys may appear normal or enlarged, but the hallmark gross finding is the presence of well-defined yellowish raised abscesses on the kidney surface. Microscopically, the inflammation is predominantly neutrophilic and begins in the tubules before extending into the interstitium. If there is significant urinary obstruction, pus may accumulate within the renal pelvis, calyces, and ureter, resulting in a condition known as pyonephrosis.

questions.text: Identify the disease pathology.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Marked dilation of the pelvis and calyces and thinning of the renal parenchyma points to a diagnosis of hydronephrosis.

  • Hydronephrosis is defined as dilation of the renal pelvis and calyces resulting from urine outflow obstruction, which leads to pressure-induced renal parenchymal atrophy.
  • Despite complete obstruction, filtration may continue for some time, causing filtrate to diffuse back into the interstitium and lymphatics.
  • Elevated pelvic pressure is transmitted through the collecting system into the renal cortex, compressing both tubules and the medullary vasculature, impairing blood flow and leading to functional disturbances such as reduced concentrating ability. Over time, interstitial inflammation develops and may culminate in fibrosis.
  • Morphologically, obstruction results in progressive pelvic and calyceal dilation, interstitial inflammation, and cortical atrophy, with chronic cases showing blunting and cupping of papillae.
  • In advanced disease, the kidney may become cystically dilated, with near-total loss of cortex.
  • While unilateral obstruction may remain silent, bilateral partial obstruction presents with polyuria and nocturia due to inability to concentrate urine, and chronic obstruction may result in tubular acidosis and secondary nephropathy.
  • Complete bilateral obstruction of rapid onset leads to anuria, incompatible with life unless promptly relieved.
  • Notably, post-obstructive diuresis can follow decompression, characterized by high-volume, sodium-rich urine output.

Explanation of other options:

Autosomal dominant polycystic disease (Option A): Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease is marked by bilaterally enlarged kidneys entirely studded with large cysts, lacking intervening parenchyma, though microscopic examination shows residual functional nephrons between cysts. The cysts themselves may contain various types of fluid, including clear, serous, turbid, or even hemorrhagic content. As they grow, the cysts can impinge on the renal pelvis and calyces, causing structural distortion.

Acute pyelonephritis (Option C): The morphological features include focal neutrophilic infiltration of the interstitium, tubular damage, and neutrophil collections within tubules that may coalesce into abscesses or wedge-shaped necrotic lesions. In the early phase, neutrophils are confined to the tubules, which serve as conduits for infection spread. As the infection advances, it extends into the interstitial tissue, leading to tubular destruction and abscess formation. Although glomeruli generally remain unaffected initially, extensive disease can ultimately compromise them.

Chronic pyelonephritis (Option D): Chronic pyelonephritis shows irregular, asymmetric scarring of the kidneys, with hallmark features including coarse corticomedullary scars overlying dilated, blunted calyces and flattened papillae, along with tubular atrophy, interstitial fibrosis, and chronic inflammation.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions usually leads to the finding given below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Gross surface is irregularly scarred. Microscopically shows changes involve predominantly tubules and interstitium. The tubules show atrophy in some areas and hypertrophy or dilation in others. Dilated tubules with flattened epithelium may be filled with casts resembling thyroid colloid (thyroidization).

questions.text: Most common histology of this gross lesion is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given gross shows renal cell carcinoma, the most common histology of which is clear cell type.

questions.text: Urine microscopy of a patient shows the following. Which of the following crystals are seen?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Envelope shaped crystals are composed of calcium oxalate dihydrate.




Explanation of other options:

Uric acid (Option B): Uric acid crystals are commonly found in acidic urine (pH 5.0-5.5) and appear in diverse shapes such as rhomboids, four-sided flat plates, prisms, and rosettes. They are typically yellow to reddish-brown, though rarely colorless and hexagonal. These crystals are soluble in alkali but insoluble in alcohol and acids, and they exhibit birefringence under polarized light. Large numbers may be seen in conditions with increased nucleoprotein turnover, such as during chemotherapy or in Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.

Cystine (Option C): Cystine crystals are colorless, hexagonal, refractile plates found in acidic urine, typically seen in individuals with cystinuria. They may resemble uric acid crystals but differ by lacking polarization unless thickly laminated, and unlike uric acid, they dissolve in dilute hydrochloric acid.

Triple phosphate (Option D): Triple phosphate crystals (ammonium magnesium phosphate) are among the most easily recognized urinary crystals. They are colorless and typically form three- to six-sided prisms with oblique ends resembling coffin lids. These crystals are most commonly seen in alkaline urine, particularly in the setting of urinary tract infections, but they generally lack significant clinical implications.

questions.text: 10/M child with generalized edema. Cholesterol 238 mg/dL. Urine protein 3+, Stool microscopy was done which shows fat in stools.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Remember the differences between nephrotic syndrome and nephritic syndrome

questions.text: 56 year old female presents with breast carcinoma, She started presenting with froathy urine. What is most common nephropathy in these cases
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common nephropathy in malignancy is membranous nephropathy.

choices.text: Only i, ii and iii are correct
Only i and iii are correct
Only ii and iv are correct

questions.text:
Which of the following statement/s is/are TRUE about membranous glomerulonephritis?
i Thickening of basement membrane
ii Most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in elderly
iii Seen in SLE, tumours, drugs
iv Deposition between endothelium and basement membrane.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Membranous nephropathy is characterized by subepithelial immunoglobulin-containing deposits along the GBM. Early in the disease, the glomeruli may appear normal by light microscopy, but well-developed cases show diffuse thickening of the capillary wall. It usually presents in adults between the ages of 30 and 60 years and follows an indolent and slowly progressive course.
  • Membranous nephropathy is a form of chronic immune complex glomerulonephritis induced by antibodies reacting in situ to endogenous or planted glomerular antigens.
  • The main histologic feature of membranous nephropathy is diffuse thickening of the capillary wall on routine H&E stains. Electron microscopy reveals that this apparent thickening is caused in part by subepithelial deposits, which nestle against the GBM and are separated from each other by small, spikelike protrusions of GBM matrix that form in reaction to the deposits (spike and dome pattern)
  • .As the disease progresses, these spikes close over the deposits, incorporating them into the GBM. In addition, as in other causes of nephrotic syndrome, the podocytes show effacement of foot processes. Later in the disease, the incorporated deposits may be broken down and eventually disappear, leaving cavities within the GBM. Continued deposition of basement membrane.matrix leads to progressive thickening of basement membranes. With further progression, glomeruli may become sclerosed.
  • Immunofluorescence microscopy shows typical granular deposits of immunoglobulins and complement along the GBM.
  • It is most common nephropathy in elderly.

questions.text: The Nephrin and Podocin are the slit diaphragm proteins responsible for maintaining glomerular permeability. Which of the following gene mutations result in a syndrome of steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome of childhood onset?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Mutation in the gene NPHS2 encoding podocin results in steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome of childhood onset.

  • The glomerulus allows passage of water and small solutes but restricts large or negatively charged proteins like albumin.
  • This selective permeability depends on both the size and charge of molecules, which is governed by the structure of the capillary wall and, importantly, the slit diaphragm.
  • The slit diaphragm is located between the foot processes of podocytes (visceral epithelial cells), and it acts as the final filtration barrier against protein loss.
  • Nephrin is a key transmembrane protein of the slit diaphragm, and it connects with other proteins such as podocin, CD2-associated protein, and the actin cytoskeleton.
  • These molecular assemblies maintain the architecture and function of the slit diaphragm.
  • Mutations in nephrin or podocin as given disrupt this barrier, leading to proteinuria and nephrotic syndromes.

Explanations of other options:

PMS2, MLH1, and MSH2 (Options A, B, and D): All are associated with mismatch repair seen in hereditary non-polyposis coli syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is responsible for basket wave appearance of the kidney?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Basket weave appearance of the glomerular basement membrane is seen in Alport syndrome which is a type of hereditary nephritis.

  • Hereditary nephritis comprises a group of familial kidney disorders resulting from collagen gene mutations that primarily damage glomeruli.
  • Among them, Alport syndrome is caused by mutations affecting type IV collagen, specifically the α3, α4, or α5 chains present in the glomerular basement membrane, lens of the eye, and cochlea.
  • This condition is commonly X-linked, especially due to COL4A5 mutations, and manifests as hematuria, progressive renal insufficiency, sensorineural hearing loss, and ocular abnormalities.
  • Morphologically, the GBM in Alport syndrome shows alternating areas of thinning and thickening, along with lamellation and splitting of the lamina densa, producing a distinctive basket-weave pattern. Tubular basement membranes may show similar changes.
  • Thin basement membrane nephropathy (benign familial hematuria), in contrast, features diffuse thinning of the GBM (150-225 nm) without other significant glomerular pathology.
  • It is inherited in an autosomal fashion, often linked to mutations in the same collagen IV genes (α3 or α4 chains), but with patients usually heterozygous and displaying excellent prognosis.
  • Unlike Alport syndrome, this condition lacks associated auditory or ocular manifestations and does not progress to renal failure in most cases.

Explanations of other options:

IgA nephropathy (Option A): IgA nephropathy, or Berger disease, is characterized by the deposition of IgA within the glomerular mesangium and typically presents with gross hematuria occurring after respiratory or gastrointestinal tract infections.

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (Option B): One of the frequent causes of nephrotic syndrome in adults, it involves focal and segmental glomerular scarring resulting from podocyte injury. presenting with significant protein loss in urine, hypertension, hematuria, and raised levels of nitrogenous waste products.

Membranous nephropathy (Option D): Typically has an insidious onset with nephrotic syndrome features like heavy proteinuria, generalized edema, and hyperlipidemia. Though it is often idiopathic, it can also be linked to secondary triggers such as drugs, infections, malignancies, or autoimmune diseases. Histologically, light microscopy shows uniformly thickened glomerular capillary walls owing to immune complex deposition, which electron microscopy confirms by identifying subepithelial electron-dense deposits along the glomerular basement membrane.

questions.text: Which one of the following is the commonest childhood renal tumour?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The commonest childhood renal tumour is nephroblastoma also known as Wilms tumour.

  • Wilms tumor, or nephroblastoma, affects ranks as the most frequent primary renal cancer in childhood, most commonly arising between ages 2 to 5.
  • About 5-10% are bilateral, either synchronous or metachronous. Pathogenesis involves defects in WT1, a gene on chromosome 11p13 crucial for renal and gonadal development.
  • Three major syndromes elevate risk: WAGR (Wilms tumor, aniridia, genitourinary anomalies, and mental retardation), Denys-Drash syndrome (gonadal dysgenesis and nephropathy), and Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (organomegaly and hemihypertrophy).
  • Morphologically, Wilms tumor presents as a large, well-circumscribed mass with tan-gray appearance and shows a triphasic pattern of blastemal, epithelial, and stromal elements.
  • Some tumors display anaplasia with pleomorphic nuclei and atypical mitoses, often due to TP53 mutations, which correlates with poor prognosis and chemotherapy resistance.
  • Nephrogenic rests, which are precursor lesions, are frequently seen, especially in bilateral cases.
  • Clinically, patients often present with an abdominal mass, hematuria, pain, or hypertension.
  • Prognosis is generally excellent with treatment, but tumors with anaplasia or specific genetic changes (like 1p/16q loss or 1q gain) have poorer outcomes.

Explanation of other options:

Renal cell Carcinoma (Option A): Renal cell carcinoma occurs more frequently in men, with a male-to-female ratio of 2:1, and is most commonly diagnosed in people between the sixth and seventh decades of life.

Oncocytoma (Option C): Oncocytoma is a non-cancerous epithelial tumor made up of large, eosinophilic cells with round, uniform nuclei and noticeable nucleoli, thought to arise from the intercalated cells of the collecting ducts, and characteristically rich in mitochondria. Macroscopically, these tumors tend to be well-defined, uniformly tan to mahogany in color, and frequently display a central stellate scar.

Angiomyolipoma (Option D): Angiomyolipoma is a non-malignant kidney tumor made up of blood vessels, smooth muscle, and fat, originating from perivascular epithelioid cells, and is linked to tuberous sclerosis, with a notable risk of spontaneous, potentially severe bleeding.

questions.text: Loss of foot process is classical is case of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Three hallmarks of minimal change disease are:

  • Diffuse loss of Podocyte foot processes
  • Vacuolation
  • Appearance of microvilli

On electron microscopy: The most characteristic feature of the minimal change disease is identified which is diffuse; flattening of foot processes of the visceral epithelial cells (podocytes) and hence, the name foot process disease or podocytopathy.

questions.text: A-51-year-old person came with complaints of hematuria to the clinic. On examination, he was normotensive and had pedal edema. Investigations revealed the patient had no glycosuria and had a creatinine value of 9. Which of the following investigations one should do to identify the etiology of the disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Goodpasture's syndrome is characterized by acute renal failure due to RPGN and pulmonary hemorrhage.
  • The condition is more common in males in 3rd decade of life.
  • The disease results from damage to the glomeruli by anti-GBM antibodies which cross react with alveolar basement membrane and hence, produce renal as well as pulmonary lesions.
  • The evidences in support are the characteristic linear deposits of anti-GBM antibodies consisting of IgG and complement along the GBM, detection of circulating anti-GBM antibodies.
  • The Goodpasture's antigen appears to be a component of collagen type IV.

questions.text: Which of the following infections is the most common within 1-4 months post transplant?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is the most prevalent viral infection following organ transplantation, posing a significant risk for graft failure and mortality, especially between 1 and 4 months post-transplant.

  • CMV infection is a frequent complication in organ transplant recipients including those of the kidney, liver, heart, lung, and others, due to their immunosuppressed state and is the most common viral pathogen complicating organ transplant. (Options B, C, and D ruled out)
  • The highest risk occurs in the first month to four months post-transplant, particularly in CMV-seronegative recipients receiving organs from CMV-seropositive donors.
  • CMV disease may manifest with fever, leukopenia, hepatitis, retinitis, gastrointestinal ulcers, or pneumonia, and the virus is known to be a major cause of morbidity and graft loss.
  • In hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HSCT) recipients, especially those with allogeneic grafts, the virus can cause viremia and severe disease if not prevented.
  • HIV-positive individuals with low CD4+ counts are also at risk, especially for CMV retinitis.
  • Clinically, "CMV syndrome" includes constitutional symptoms, cytopenias, and liver involvement, potentially progressing to multiorgan complications if untreated.
  • CMV colitis is the most common gastrointestinal manifestation in transplant settings, and its diagnosis may require tissue biopsy, as antigenemia and viral load tests might be negative in intestinal disease.

questions.text: A patient presents with features of chronic kidney disease such as oliguria, edema, and hypertension. As a part of investigative workup, urine microscopy was done which showed the following finding. Identify the structure marked by the arrow.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The arrow points to waxy casts which are commonly seen in chronic kidney disease.

  • Casts are the only formed elements of urine that originate exclusively from the kidney, specifically from Tamm-Horsfall protein secreted in the thick ascending limb of Henle.
  • These proteins create a scaffold that can trap other elements like cells, debris, or granules, forming various types of casts depending on content and conditions.
  • Hyaline casts, made purely of protein, can be seen in both normal and pathological states but are often more abundant in kidney disease.
  • Waxy casts represent a more advanced stage of cast formation and appear as dense, homogeneous, and refractile, commonly occurring in chronic renal disease.
  • They form as a result of extreme stasis or obstruction and are associated with severe nephron injury, such as tubular atrophy or dilation.
  • When waxy casts are abnormally wide, they are referred to as "renal failure casts" and signify end-stage renal pathology.

Explanation of other options:

Decoy cell (Option A): Decoy cells are infected renal epithelial cells with viral inclusion bodies. It is commonly seen in immunocompromised patients, especially renal transplant recipients and is a key marker for polyomavirus (e.g., BK virus) infection.

Tubular epithelial cell (Option B): Renal tubular epithelial cells in urine are key indicators of tubular injury, particularly in conditions like acute tubular necrosis (ATN) or toxic kidney injury, and their presence in elevated numbers signifies damage to the renal tubules.

Charcot leyden crystal (Option C): Charcot-Leyden crystals are formed from a protein called galectin-10 found within eosinophils and are often observed in the sputum of individuals with asthma.

questions.text: Identify the stones marked by the arrow in the given urine routine microscopy image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given image shows coffin-lid shaped crystals which are struvite stones.

Here are common types of crystals that may be found in urine:

Explanations of other options:

Uric acid (Option A): Uric acid crystals typically form in acidic urine and display a variety of shapes and colors and can take on several forms, including rhomboids, flat four-sided plates, rosettes, or prism-like shapes. Most are yellow to reddish-brown in color and a high number of these crystals may be present in patients undergoing chemotherapy or those with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.

Ca oxalate (Option B): Calcium oxalate stones can be either the more commonly seen dihydrate variety which are envelope shaped or the less commonly seen calcium oxalate monohydrate which is dumb-bell shaped.

Cystine (Option D): Cystine crystals are hexagonal, colorless structures seen in acidic urine of patients with cystinuria. A key distinguishing feature compared to uric acid crystals is their ability to dissolve in dilute hydrochloric acid, unlike uric acid crystals.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with hematuria. Investigations revealed normal glucose levels, proteinuria and creatinine of 9 mg%. Electron microscopic image is shown below. What other investigations could help in the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

EM image shows rupture of GBM. With a history to proteinuria and hypertension and high creatinine, RPGN can be an important differential.

questions.text: Immunofluorescence staining pattern from the kidney biopsy of a 35-year-old patient presenting with proteinuria is shown below. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The immunofluorescence staining pattern shows the full-house effect which is seen in lupus nephritis.

  • Lupus nephritis (LN) refers to kidney involvement in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), an autoimmune disease marked by the production of antinuclear antibodies.
  • LN can affect any part of the renal parenchyma - glomeruli, tubules, vessels, or interstitium, but glomerular involvement is the most clinically significant due to its link to morbidity and mortality.
  • Classification systems like the ISN/RPS divide LN into six types (class I to VI) based on the pattern and severity of immune complex deposition and glomerular involvement.
  • Class IV, diffuse proliferative LN, is the most frequently encountered and severe form, characterized by endocapillary hypercellularity, wire-loop lesions, and subendothelial deposits.
  • Immunofluorescence (IF) typically shows "full house" staining for IgG, IgA, IgM, and complement (C1q, C3).
  • Another variant called lupus podocytopathy shows podocyte injury without classic immune deposits and mimics minimal change disease or FSGS.
  • Pathogenesis involves autoantibodies, immune complexes, complement activation, and dysregulated B- and T-cell activity, with nonimmune contributors like hypoxia and vascular injury.

Explanation of other options:

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (Option A): A common cause of nephrotic syndrome this condition shows segmental scarring in some glomeruli under light microscopy, widespread foot process loss on electron microscopy, and often IgM and C3 staining in affected regions on immunofluorescence.

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (Option B): Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis typically arises after a streptococcal throat or skin infection, characterized by immune complex-mediated inflammation leading to enlarged, hypercellular glomeruli and granular IgG and C3 deposits on immunofluorescence.

Good Pasture syndrome (Option D): Good pasture syndrome is an autoimmune disorder where antibodies attack the α3 noncollagenous region of type IV collagen, resulting in rapidly worsening glomerulonephritis and bleeding in the lungs, with linear deposition of immunoglobulins and complement seen on immunofluorescence.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with complaints for frothy urine and facial puffiness. The DIF and electron microscopic picture of the patient is given below. Diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given image shows Membranous glomerulopathy with diffuse capillary wall thickening in EM image and granular (IgG and C3 deposits) in immunofluorescence.

questions.text: Given below is the immunofluorescence image of kidney biopsy. Identify the condition:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Whenever you get an immunofluorescence image in a kidney biopsy, you must try to see, if the deposits look granular (lumpy bumpy) or linear.
  • If it is linear, the answer will be Goodpasture's syndrome (Anti GBM antibody ds)
  • If it is granular, it can be any other immune complex disease. Among the given options, the only immune complex deposition disease is Membranous nephropathy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with hematuria. Renal biopsy demonstrates a focal necrotizing glomerulitis with crescent formation. The patient also gives a history of intermittent hemoptysis and intermittent chest pain of moderate intensity. A previous chest X-ray had demonstrated multiple opacities, some of which were cavitated. What is the most likely diagnosis based on these features?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the given clinical features of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, intermittent hemoptysis and cavitatory lung lesions, the most likely diagnosis is granulomatosis with polyangiitis.

  • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), formerly called Wegener granulomatosis, is a systemic necrotizing vasculitis that classically presents with a triad: necrotizing granulomas in the upper and/or lower respiratory tract, vasculitis involving small- to medium-sized vessels, and glomerulonephritis, often with crescent formation.
  • It may appear in a limited form affecting only the respiratory tract or as a widespread disease with systemic involvement including skin, eyes, heart, and kidneys.
  • Pathogenesis likely involves a T-cell mediated hypersensitivity to environmental antigens, with granulomas supporting this immune mechanism.
  • Over 90% of cases show PR3-ANCA (previously c-ANCA) positivity, which serves as both a diagnostic and prognostic marker, with titers correlating with disease activity and relapse.
  • Morphologically, the respiratory lesions range from mucosal granulomas to extensive geographic necrosis with vasculitis. Lung lesions can cavitate and become radiographically visible, with hemorrhage and fibrosis occurring in advanced stages.
  • Renal manifestations range from focal necrosis to crescentic glomerulonephritis.
  • Clinically, the disease more commonly affects men around the age of 40 and additional features include rash, joint and nerve involvement, and fever.
  • Untreated GPA has a high fatality rate, but aggressive therapy using corticosteroids, cyclophosphamide, TNF blockers, and B-cell-directed therapy can convert it into a relapsing-remitting condition.

Explanations of other options:

Aspergillosis (Option A): Aspergillosis can trigger hypersensitivity reactions like allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis in healthy individuals while colonizing aspergillosis, or aspergilloma, typically arises in lung cavities from previous diseases like TB or bronchiectasis, forming fungus balls with minimal tissue invasion but potential for hemoptysis. In contrast, invasive aspergillosis causes necrotizing pneumonia with sharply demarcated lesions, often spreading hematogenously to the heart and brain.

Polyarteritis nodosa (Option B): Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is a necrotizing vasculitis of small- and medium-sized muscular arteries, sparing pulmonary vessels, that presents with variable systemic symptoms and potentially fatal organ ischemia but responds well to immunosuppressive therapy. Around one-third of cases are linked to chronic hepatitis B virus due to immune complex deposition.

Renal carcinoma metastatic to lung (Option C): The lungs are the most common site for metastatic spread. Morphologically, the usual manifestation involves numerous discrete, rounded nodules, often referred to as "cannonball lesions", dispersed throughout all lobes, especially near the lung periphery. However, metastasis can also present as a single nodule, infiltrative growths along bronchi or pleura, consolidation resembling pneumonia, or combinations of these patterns.

questions.text: A patient presenting with haemoptysis and renal failure with anti-basement membrane antibodies positives on renal biopsy. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Anti-GBM antibody-mediated crescentic GN (Goodpasture disease) is characterized by linear deposits of IgG and, in many cases, C3 in the GBM.
  • In some patients, the anti-GBM antibodies also bind to pulmonary alveolar capillary basement membranes to produce the clinical picture of pulmonary hemorrhages associated with renal failure. These patients are said to have Goodpasture syndrome. Anti-GBM antibodies are present in the serum and are helpful in diagnosis.
  • It is important to recognize anti-GBM antibody-mediated crescentic GN, because affected individuals benefit from plasmapheresis, which removes pathogenic antibodies from the circulation.

questions.text: Gross section of the kidney specimen shown below suggests a diagnosis of?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given kidney specimen depicts cysts in the cortex as well as medulla with no normal intervening parenchyma which points to a diagnosis of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease.

  • Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is a hereditary disorder marked by progressive cyst formation in both kidneys leading to renal failure, with systemic complications and significant genetic heterogeneity involving PKD1 and PKD2 mutations.
  • ADPKD is inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion with high penetrance. Although the trait is dominant, both alleles must be nonfunctional due to a germline mutation in one allele (typically inherited) and a somatic mutation in the other for the disease to manifest.
  • The disease is usually bilateral, and unilateral cases suggest multicystic dysplasia.
  • Renal function is preserved until the fourth or fifth decade as the cysts initially involve only a small number of nephrons.
  • PKD1 mutations on chromosome 16 (encoding polycystin-1) account for 85% of cases and are associated with a more severe disease course, with renal failure risk rising with age.
  • PKD2 mutations on chromosome 4 (encoding polycystin-2) are linked to a milder phenotype.
  • The pathogenesis involves altered mechanosensation and calcium flux due to disrupted primary cilia function, which ultimately impairs tubular epithelial cell proliferation and fluid regulation, promoting cyst growth.
  • Cysts arise from all segments of the nephron and contain fluid ranging from clear to hemorrhagic. They may compress calyces and pelvis, causing pressure defects.
  • Patients may remain asymptomatic until renal insufficiency emerges. Hematuria, proteinuria, abdominal pain, and hypertension are common presentations. Disease severity is increased in males, African descent, and in association with sickle cell trait.
  • Some common associations include hepatic cysts, and less frequently, cysts in spleen, pancreas, and lungs. Intracranial berry aneurysms and mitral valve prolapse are also seen in conjunction with this condition in some cases.

Cystic diseases of the kidney are summarized in the table given below.


Explanations of other options:

Renal cell cancer (Option A): The most common variant, clear cell carcinoma, usually appears as a single, round, yellow-gray lesion in the renal cortex, marked by fat deposition, areas of bleeding and necrosis, and well-defined borders.

Medullary sponge kidney (Option B): Medullary sponge kidney is a benign condition in adults marked by dilated collecting ducts in the renal medulla with small cysts, typically found incidentally on imaging and usually without functional impairment.

Hydatid cyst (Option C): Hydatid cyst commonly affects the liver and lungs. Rarely, it may spread to adjacent structures from the liver such as the kidney or diaphragm.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male with a history with hematuria, hypertension, and a palpable abdominal mass dies due to a complication of the underlying condition. Which of the following is the least likely cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given features suggest a diagnosis of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease in which hepatic fibrosis is not a cause of death.

  • Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is a genetic disorder involving bilateral renal cyst development that progressively leads to renal failure, with systemic manifestations and genetic variability predominantly linked to PKD1 and PKD2 mutations.
  • In the early stages, only a small proportion of nephrons are affected, allowing normal kidney function to persist until middle age.
  • The majority of cases (about 85%) are caused by mutations in the PKD1 gene on chromosome 16, which encodes polycystin-1, and are associated with more severe clinical outcomes. Mutations in PKD2 on chromosome 4, encoding polycystin-2, tend to cause a milder disease.
  • Disruption of normal ciliary function in tubular epithelial cells impairs calcium signaling and mechanosensation, leading to abnormal cell proliferation, fluid secretion, and progressive cyst formation.
  • The cysts originate from various parts of the nephron and may enlarge enough to compress surrounding renal structures, producing pressure-related changes.
  • Patients may remain symptom-free until renal dysfunction becomes apparent, often manifesting as hematuria, proteinuria, flank pain, or hypertension. Disease severity may be influenced by sex (more severe in males), ethnicity (more severe in individuals of African descent), and comorbidities like sickle cell trait.
  • Extra-renal associations include liver cysts, and less commonly, cysts in the pancreas, lungs, or spleen. Cardiovascular complications like mitral valve prolapse and neurological risks such as berry aneurysms may also be present.
  • Death can occur due to coronary artery disease or complications of hypertension, infections, ruptured cerebral aneurysms or hypertensive brain hemorrhages. (Options A, C, and D ruled out)

questions.text: A 55-year male patient with persistent high blood pressure presents to you with a headache .Ophthalmological evaluation reveals papilledema. What is your diagnosis from the given history and microscopy findings of renal biopsy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given histopathological image shows hyperplastic arteriosclerosis leading to the characteristic onion-skin lesions which arise due to malignant hypertension.

  • Malignant hypertension is a severe and rapidly progressive form of hypertension that affects approximately 5% of hypertensive individuals. It is defined by extremely elevated blood pressure (systolic >200 mm Hg and diastolic >120 mm Hg), which if left untreated can lead to death within 1-2 years.
  • Clinically, it presents with signs of end-organ damage such as renal failure and retinal hemorrhages with or without papilledema. It may arise de novo or superimpose on pre-existing benign hypertension.
  • Renal lesions in malignant hypertension are referred to as malignant nephrosclerosis. The kidneys may either retain their normal size or become reduced.
  • A notable macroscopic finding is the appearance of minute petechial hemorrhages on the kidney surface, caused by ruptured glomerular capillaries or arterioles, giving it a typical "flea-bitten" look.
  • On histolopathological examination, arterioles exhibit fibrinoid necrosis, characterized by a strongly eosinophilic, granular texture due to necrotic material and extravasated plasma proteins.
  • In larger arterioles and interlobular arteries, hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis, which involves concentric, laminated thickening of the arterial walls composed of smooth muscle cell proliferation and duplicated basement membranes. This creates an "onion-skin" appearance and leads to significant luminal narrowing or even obliteration.
  • This change causes narrowing or complete blockage of the vessel lumen, leading to reduced blood supply.
  • Glomerular involvement may also be seen, with areas of necrosis and sometimes the presence of microthrombi within the glomerular capillaries.

Explanation of other options:

Minimal change disease(Option A): The most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children which shows no changes on light microscopy.

Diabetic nephropathy (Option B): Light microscopy showing glomerular basement membrane thickening, diffuse mesangial sclerosis, and nodular glomerulosclerosis (Kimmelstein-Wilson lesions).

Benign nephrosclerosis (Option D): Benign hypertension is associated with hyaline arteriolosclerosis, a vascular change characterized by uniform thickening of the arteriolar walls due to the deposition of pink, glassy (hyaline) material. In the kidneys, the resultant luminal narrowing leads to ischemic injury and glomerular scarring (nephrosclerosis), causing progressive compromise in renal perfusion. Although similar vascular alterations may be seen in normotensive elderly individuals, the changes are more widespread and severe in hypertensive patients.

questions.text: Identify the morphology in the blood vessel of given H & E stain section that favours the diagnosis of benign hypertension?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In benign (long-standing, moderate) hypertension, persistent hemodynamic stress causes homogeneous, pink hyaline thickening of the walls of small arteries and arterioles termed hyaline arteriolosclerosis.
  • This change results from plasma protein leakage across injured endothelial cells and enhanced extracellular matrix production by smooth muscle cells. These vascular alterations narrow the lumens, reducing blood flow and producing ischemic injury to the renal parenchyma.
  • Consequently, there is patchy tubular atrophy, interstitial fibrosis, and glomerular changes such as sclerosis and basement membrane collapse.
  • The interlobular and arcuate arteries also exhibit medial hypertrophy, duplication of the internal elastic lamina, and accumulation of myofibroblastic tissue within the intima, collectively contributing to narrowing of the vascular lumen.
  • Grossly, the kidneys are either normal-sized or slightly reduced with a finely granular surface resembling grain leather.
  • In contrast, malignant hypertension leads to changes like hyperplastic arteriosclerosis giving rise to characteristic onion-skin lesions, and fibrinoid necrosis of vessel walls. (Options A, B, and D ruled out)

choices.text: Only i, ii, and iii are correct
Only i and iii are correct
Only ii and iv are correct

questions.text:
Which of following gross features is/are seen in specimen of benign nephrosclerosis?
i. Flea-bitten appearance
ii. U shape scar on cortical surface
iii. Pale yellow abscess formation
iv. Grain leather appearance
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Nephrosclerosis refers to sclerosis of small renal arteries and arterioles that is strongly associated with hypertension. The characteristic morphologic alterations of the small arterioles are called hyaline arteriolosclerosis, while the arteries show fibrous intimal and medial thickening often resulting in luminal narrowing.
  • The vascular changes cause ischemia, which leads to various combinations of interstitial fibrosis, tubular atrophy, and focal global glomerulosclerosis.
  • Grossly, the kidneys are symmetrically atrophic. Typically the renal surface shows diffuse, fine granularity that resembles grain leather.
  • Others are the features of malignant nephrosclerosis.

questions.text: Which of the following glomerular lesions is seen in reflux nephropathy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The glomerular lesion seen in reflux nephropathy is focal segmental glomerulosclerosis.

  • Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is one of the leading cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults and primarily arises from injury to podocytes, much like minimal change disease.
  • Histologically, it is defined by sclerosis affecting only a portion (segmental) of some (focal) glomeruli. Clinically, FSGS presents with proteinuria that may be in the nephrotic or non-nephrotic range, often accompanied by microscopic hematuria, hypertension, and varying degrees of azotemia. The onset may be subtle or subacute.
  • FSGS is classified into several forms: idiopathic (primary), secondary to other conditions like HIV infection, heroin use, sickle cell disease, or obesity, as an adaptive response in conditions like reflux nephropathy or unilateral renal agenesis; and in hereditary forms involving mutations in genes like NPHS1 (nephrin), NPHS2 (podocin), ACTN4 (α-actinin 4), or TRPC6. These mutations affect components of the slit diaphragm or podocyte structure and function.
  • Pathologically, FSGS is marked by focal podocyte injury, with effacement of foot processes, plasma protein entrapment, and extracellular matrix accumulation leading to hyalinosis and sclerosis.
  • Morphologically, lesions are patchy and may be missed on biopsy. Common findings include foam cells, hyalinosis, and collapse of capillary loops.
  • One notable variant is "collapsing glomerulopathy," seen in HIV-associated nephropathy, which shows segmental or global collapse of glomerular tufts, prominent epithelial proliferation, and often carries a poor prognosis.
  • Approximately 20% of patients experience rapid progression to renal failure within 2 years, especially those with heavy proteinuria, low initial GFR, or those with the collapsing variant. The tip lesion variant has a more favorable outlook.

Explanations of other options:

Membranous nephropathy (Option B): It typically presents slowly with features of nephrotic syndrome, including heavy proteinuria, generalized edema, and hyperlipidemia. Although frequently idiopathic, it can also arise from secondary factors such as drugs, infections, malignancies, or autoimmune diseases.

Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis type I (Option C): Type I membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis is characterized by the deposition of immune complexes composed of IgG and complement, which results in glomerular enlargement and increased cellularity.

Minimal change disease (Option D): The leading cause of nephrotic syndrome in children between 2 and 6 years of age is characterized by widespread loss of podocyte foot processes observable under electron microscopy, while light microscopy reveals no structural abnormalities.

questions.text: Which is NOT a feature of benign hypertension in Kidney?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Fibrinoid necrosis is the characteristic finding of malignant hypertension.
  • Malignant hypertension, defined as blood pressure usually greater than 200/120 mm Hg.
  • The kidney may be normal in size or shrunken, depending on the duration and severity of the hypertensive disease.
  • Small, pinpoint petechial hemorrhages may appear on the cortical surface from rupture of arterioles or glomerular capillaries, giving the kidney a peculiar, flea-bitten appearance.
  • The microscopic changes reflect the pathogenetic events discussed earlier. Damage to the small vessels is manifested as fibrinoid necrosis of the arterioles.
  • The vessel walls show a homogeneous, granular eosinophilic appearance masking underlying detail. In the interlobular arteries and larger arterioles, proliferation of intimal cells after acute injury produces an onion-skin appearance.
  • This name is derived from the concentric arrangement of cells whose origin is believed to be intimal smooth muscle, although this issue has not been finally settled.
  • This lesion, called hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis, causes marked narrowing of arterioles and small arteries, to the point of total obliteration

Fibrinoid necrosis is the death of cells in small blood vessels. It can lead to bleeding and internal damage throughout the body. Many conditions can cause fibrinoid necrosis, including malignant hypertension and autoimmune diseases.

choices.text: Only ii and iii are correct
Only i and iii are correct
Only ii and iv are correct

questions.text:
Predominant subepithelial deposits in the kidney are/are seen in which of the following conditions?
i MPGN-1( Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis)
ii PSGN(Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis) iii Membranous nephropathy
iv Good-pasture syndrome
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Among the given options, subepithelial deposits are seen in post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis and membranous nephropathy, i.e. only ii and iii are correct.

  • Subepithelial deposits are visualised on electron microscopy as electron-dense deposits between the outer surface of glomerular basement membrane and the podocytes.
  • On electron microscopy, the hallmark feature in post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is the presence of distinct, electron-dense deposits located on the outer (epithelial) side of the glomerular basement membrane. These deposits often appear as "humps" and are thought to represent antigen-antibody complexes situated at the subepithelial surface.
  • In membranous nephropathy, electron microscopy reveals that the basement membrane thickening results from uneven electron-dense immune complex deposits located between the basement membrane and the overlying epithelial cells, along with widespread flattening of podocyte foot processes. New basement membrane material forms between these deposits, creating irregular spike-like projections extending from the GBM. These spikes are most clearly visualized with silver stains, which stain the basement membrane black while leaving the deposits unstained. Over time, these projections enlarge into dome-shaped structures and eventually grow over the immune deposits, embedding them within a significantly thickened and irregular glomerular basement membrane. The electron microscopic appearance is as shown below with the subepithelial deposits marked by the arrows.
  • Type I membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis is defined by distinct electron-dense deposits located in the subendothelial region. In addition, deposits may also be found within the mesangium and, at times, beneath the epithelial layer. (Option B ruled out)
  • Electron microscopy in Goodpasture syndrome may reveal electron-dense fibrin fragments but immune complex deposits are not observed. (Options C and D ruled out)

The various renal pathologies with predominant pattern of electron-dense deposits is given in the table given below.

questions.text: A 40-year-old hypertensive male was admitted to the hospital with sudden onset of headache and altered sensorium. On Examination his Blood Pressure was observed to be 220/110mm Hg and the patient died four later. What is likely pathological finding in his kidneys -
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is a case of a middle aged man who died of malignant hypertension Kidneys in such patients have a characteristic flea-bitten appearance i.e. Small kidney with petechial hemorrhages.
